7.heading: The Glob.
7.title: "The Shangri-La Syndrome!"
7.author: Len Wein, writer ; Sal Buscema & Joe Staton, illustrators ; Glynis Wein, colorist ; John Costanza, letterer
7.appears_in: 17 p. in The Incredible Hulk, no. 198 (Apr. 1976)
notes: Cover title: Museum of the Mad!

SUMMARY: The Glob, Man-Thing and The Hulk have been captured by The Collector for his private spaceship/ museum; The Hulk leads a revolt of the exhibits, who have been held for many years, but upon leaving the museum age catches up with them and they crumble. I. [Each creator] II. The Incredible Hulk. III. Museum of the Mad! k. Madness. k. Syndromes. k. The Glob. k. Man-Thing. k. The Hulk. k. The Collector. k. Museums. k. Exhibits. k. Age. k. Crumbling. 16.heading: Global Domination.
16.title: Excel Saga
16.author: story and art by Rikdo Koshi.
notes: (Viz Graphic Novel)

Summary (from OCLC): In an underground base far below the city, the organization of ACROSS secretly plots to conquer the world... the problem is ACROSS only consists of two members. Japanese teenager Excel is ACROSS's sole operative, fiercely devoted to her overlord Ilpalazzo's vision of global domination. Ilpalazzo, though, is more interested in rock music and video games.

Appearance of Inza Kramer.

109.title: "Globos Globales : 1980-2000"
109.author: Armando Bartra
109.series: Debut, Beneficio y Despedida de una Narrativa Tumultuaria ; 3
109.appears_in: p. 225-236 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 1, no. 4 (Dic. 2001).
notes: Resumen: "En esta última etapa Armando Bartra nos ofrece un preciso diagnóstico (que en ciertos aspectos se antoja autopsia) de la vapuleada historieta mexicana. A través de su incisiva pluma presenciamos la caída de la forma narrativa que mantuvo alfabetizado al publo mexicano durante décadas. Atestiguamos también el surgimiento y desarrollo incipiente de la historieta de autor oriunda de estas tierras, y nos enfrentamos a la responsibilidad de prever y ayudar a construir un futuro todavía incierto."

Abstract: In this last chapter of his Mexican historieta overview, Armando Bartra offers us a diagnostic summary (in certain ways an autopsy) of the maligned Mexican graphic narrative. Through his incisive writing we see the fall of the narrative form which kept the Mexican people literate for decades. We also witness the rise and beginning development of a comic native to the country, and we face the responsibility to envision and help build a still-uncertain future.
Abstracts as published with the article, with some editing of the English.
Includes illustrations.
